hyp_text: The most common cause of diabetes insipidus is damage to the hypothalamus or pituitary gland either from surgery, infection, inflammation, a tumor, or a head injury. This disrupts the normal production, storage, and release of vasopressin from the hypothalamus and into the bloodstream via the pituitary gland. The ADH deficiency can be either partial or complete. This form of diabetes insipidus is called "central diabetes insipidus" when it involves a problem with the hypothalamus, or "neurogenic diabetes insipidus" when the problem lies in the pituitary (neuro-) gland. In some people, the ADH deficiency appears to be due to an autoimmune reaction against the ADH-producing cells in the hypothalamus.

Based in Colorado Springs, Colorado, it was founded in 1895 and has been headquartered there since 1978. Its creation was sanctioned on June 27, 1950, under the Amateur Sports Act as the coordinator of amateur sports in the United States responsible for training, entering and underwriting costs for the U.S. teams in the Olympic, Paralympic, Youth Olympic, Pan American, and Parapan American Games. The USOC is one of only four NOCs in the world that also manage the Paralympic Games. The USOC is responsible for supporting, entering and overseeing U.S. teams for the Olympic Games, Paralympic Games, Youth Olympic Games, Pan American Games, and Parapan American Games and serves as the National Paralympic Committee (NPC) for the United States. Membership in the USOC consists of the National Governing Bodies recognized by the USOC, the U.S. members of the International Federations, certain Multisport Organizations, the Paralympic Sports Clubs, and certain individuals.

ref_text: The Sundarbans are the largest littoral mangrove belt in the world, stretching 80 km (50 mi) into the Bangladeshi and Indian hinterland from the coast.
hyp_text: The Sundarbans is a vast forest in the coastal region of the Bay of Bengal; considered one of the natural wonders of the world, it was recognised in 1997 as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The Sundarbans is a cluster of low-lying islands in the Bay of Bengal, spread across India and Bangladesh, famous for its unique mangrove forests. This active delta region is among the largest in the world, measuring roughly about 80 km (50mi) wide and 100 km (62mi) long. The Sundarbans is intersected by a complex network of tidal waterways, mudflats and small islands of salt-tolerant mangrove forests. The area is known for its wide range of fauna. The present Sundarbans National Park was declared as the core area of Sundarbans Tiger Reserve in 1973 and a wildlife sanctuary in 1977. On 4 May 1984 it was declared a National Park. It is a UNESCO world heritage site inscribed in 1987. It is considered as a World Network of Biosphere Reserve (Man and Biosphere Reserve) in 2001.

hyp_text: The "Aymara" are a group of indigenous people who live in the Andes and Altiplano regions of South America; some 2 million live in Bolivia, Peru and Chile. Their ancestors lived in the region for many centuries before becoming a subject people of the Inca in the late 15th or early 16th century, and later of the Spanish in the 16th century. With the Spanish American Wars of Independence (1810–25), the Aymaras became subjects of the new nations of Bolivia and Peru. After the War of the Pacific (1879–83), Chile annexed territory occupied by the Aymaras. Archeologists have found evidence that the Aymaras have occupied the Andes, in what is now western Bolivia, southern Peru and northern Chile, for at least 800 years (or more than 5,000 years, according to some estimates). Their origin is a matter of scientific dispute.
